Returns: a string representation of the object.
toString().Description: Returns a string representation of the object. In general, the toString method returns a string that "textually represents" this object. The result should be a concise but informative representation that is easy for a person to read. It is recommended that all subclasses override this method. The toString method for class Object returns a string consisting of the name of the class of which the object is an instance, the at-sign character `@', and the unsigned hexadecimal representation of the hash code of the object. In other words, this method returns a string equal to the value of:

getPort().Description: Get the bound port of the wrapped socket.

finalize().Description: Check that the socket was closed properly.

close().Description: Close this socket. This closes the wrapped socket. Open encapsulation sockets count against a user's resource limits, and forgetting to close them eventually will result in @B_android#net#IpSecManager#ResourceUnavailableException_E@ being thrown.

getFileDescriptor().Description: Get the encapsulation socket's file descriptor.

ClassDesc: This class provides access to a UDP encapsulation Socket. UdpEncapsulationSocket wraps a system-provided datagram socket intended for IKEv2 signalling and UDP encapsulated IPsec traffic. Instances can be obtained by calling @B_android#net#IpSecManager#openUdpEncapsulationSocket_E@. The provided socket cannot be re-bound by the caller. The caller should not close the FileDescriptor returned by @B_android#net#IpSecManager#UdpEncapsulationSocket#getFileDescriptor_E@, but should use @B_android#net#IpSecManager#UdpEncapsulationSocket#close_E@ instead. Allowing the user to close or unbind a UDP encapsulation socket could impact the traffic of the next user who binds to that port. To prevent this scenario, these sockets are held open by the system so that they may only be closed by calling @B_android#net#IpSecManager#UdpEncapsulationSocket#close_E@ or when the user process exits.
